title: Why do atoms vibrate all the time and why do they vibrate faster when heated? - Quora

response.answer_text: Thermal energy induces molecular motion aka oscillations of the EM fields surrounding the atomic nuclei. At zero degrees Kelvin (hypothetically) all oscillations cease. The frequency of oscillation is a function of EM structure; it’s the amplitude of oscillation that varies with magnitude of thermal energy being processed.

The forces that bind atoms together have a small component of “springiness”, which allows them to vibrate like spring oscillators. Heat is simply a measure of that vibrational energy, so adding heat (aka raising the temperature) increases the amount of vibration.
